sn42.2:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn42.2:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn42.2:1.2.pli: Atha kho tālapuṭo naṭagāmaṇi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho tālapuṭo naṭagāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn42.2:1.2.eng: Then Tālapuṭa the dancing master came up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:

sn42.2:1.3.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante, pubbakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ naṭānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:
sn42.2:1.3.eng: “Sir, I have heard that the dancers of the past who were tutors of tutors said:

sn42.2:1.4.pli: ‘yo so naṭo raṅgamajjhe samajjamajjhe saccālikena janaṃ hāseti rameti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pahāsānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī’ti.
sn42.2:1.4.eng: ‘Suppose a dancer entertains and amuses people on a stage or at a festival with truth and lies. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of laughing gods.’

sn42.2:1.5.eng: What does the Buddha say about this?”

sn42.2:1.6.pli: “Alaṃ, gāmaṇi, tiṭṭhatetaṃ. Mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī”ti.
sn42.2:1.6.eng: “Enough, chief, let it be. Don’t ask me that.”

sn42.2:1.7.pli: Dutiyampi kho tālapuṭo naṭagāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

sn42.2:1.8.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante, pubbakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ naṭānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:

sn42.2:1.9.pli: ‘yo so naṭo raṅgamajjhe samajjamajjhe saccālikena janaṃ hāseti rameti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pahāsānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī’ti.

sn42.2:1.11.pli: “Alaṃ, gāmaṇi, tiṭṭhatetaṃ. Mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī”ti.

sn42.2:1.12.pli: Tatiyampi kho tālapuṭo naṭagāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn42.2:1.12.eng: And for a third time Tālapuṭa said to the Buddha:

sn42.2:1.13.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante, pubbakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ naṭānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:
sn42.2:1.13.eng: “Sir, I have heard that the dancers of the past who were tutors of tutors said:

sn42.2:1.14.pli: ‘yo so naṭo raṅgamajjhe samajjamajjhe saccālikena janaṃ hāseti rameti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pahāsānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī’ti.
sn42.2:1.14.eng: ‘Suppose a dancer entertains and amuses people on a stage or at a festival with truth and lies. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of laughing gods.’

sn42.2:1.15.eng: What does the Buddha say about this?”

sn42.2:2.1.eng: “Clearly, chief, I’m not getting through to you when I say:

sn42.2:2.5.pli: Pubbe kho, gāmaṇi, sattā avītarāgā rāgabandhanabaddhā.
sn42.2:2.5.eng: When sentient beings are still not free of greed, and are still bound by greed,

sn42.2:2.6.pli: Tesaṃ naṭo raṅgamajjhe samajjamajjhe ye dhammā rajanīyā te upasaṃharati bhiyyoso mattāya.
sn42.2:2.6.eng: a dancer in a stage or festival presents them with even more arousing things.

sn42.2:2.7.pli: Pubbe kho, gāmaṇi, sattā avītadosā dosabandhanabaddhā.
sn42.2:2.7.eng: When sentient beings are still not free of hate, and are still bound by hate,

sn42.2:2.8.pli: Tesaṃ naṭo raṅgamajjhe samajjamajjhe ye dhammā dosanīyā te upasaṃharati bhiyyoso mattāya.
sn42.2:2.8.eng: a dancer in a stage or festival presents them with even more hateful things.

sn42.2:2.9.pli: Pubbe kho, gāmaṇi, sattā avītamohā mohabandhanabaddhā.
sn42.2:2.9.eng: When sentient beings are still not free of delusion, and are still bound by delusion,

sn42.2:2.10.pli: Tesaṃ naṭo raṅgamajjhe samajjamajjhe ye dhammā mohanīyā te upasaṃharati bhiyyoso mattāya.
sn42.2:2.10.eng: a dancer in a stage or festival presents them with even more delusory things.

sn42.2:2.11.pli: So attanā matto pamatto pare madetvā pamādetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pahāso nāma nirayo tattha upapajjati.
sn42.2:2.11.eng: And so, being heedless and negligent themselves, they’ve encouraged others to be heedless and negligent. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the hell called ‘Laughter’.

sn42.2:2.12.eng: But if you have such a view:

sn42.2:2.13.pli: ‘yo so naṭo raṅgamajjhe samajjamajjhe saccālikena janaṃ hāseti rameti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pahāsānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī’ti, sāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi.
sn42.2:2.13.eng: ‘Suppose a dancer entertains and amuses people on a stage or at a festival with truth and lies. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of laughing gods.’ This is your wrong view.

sn42.2:2.14.pli: Micchādiṭṭhikassa kho panāhaṃ, gāmaṇi, purisapuggalassa dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ vadāmi—
sn42.2:2.14.eng: An individual with wrong view is reborn in one of two places, I say:

sn42.2:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, tālapuṭo naṭagāmaṇi parodi assūni pavattesi.
sn42.2:3.1.eng: When he said this, Tālapuṭa cried and burst out in tears.

sn42.2:3.2.eng: “This is what I didn’t get through to you when I said:

sn42.2:3.3.pli: ‘alaṃ, gāmaṇi, tiṭṭhatetaṃ; mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī’”ti.
sn42.2:3.3.eng: ‘Enough, chief, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’”

sn42.2:3.4.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhante, etaṃ rodāmi yaṃ maṃ bhagavā evamāha;
sn42.2:3.4.eng: “Sir, I’m not crying because of what the Buddha said.

sn42.2:3.5.pli: api cāhaṃ, bhante, pubbakehi ācariyapācariyehi naṭehi dīgharattaṃ nikato vañcito paluddho:
sn42.2:3.5.eng: But sir, for a long time I’ve been cheated, tricked, and deceived by the dancers of the past who were tutors of tutors, who said:

sn42.2:3.6.pli: ‘yo so naṭo raṅgamajjhe samajjamajjhe saccālikena janaṃ hāseti rameti so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pahāsānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī’”ti.
sn42.2:3.6.eng: ‘Suppose a dancer entertains and amuses people on a stage or at a festival with truth and lies. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of laughing gods.’

sn42.2:3.8.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
sn42.2:3.8.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.

sn42.2:3.9.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
sn42.2:3.9.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

sn42.2:3.10.pli: Labheyyāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
sn42.2:3.10.eng: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”

sn42.2:3.11.pli: Alattha kho tālapuṭo naṭagāmaṇi bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
sn42.2:3.11.eng: And the dancing master Tālapuṭa received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

sn42.2:3.12.eng: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Tālapuṭa

sn42.3:1.1.pli: Atha kho yodhājīvo gāmaṇi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho yodhājīvo gāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn42.3:1.1.eng: Then Dustin the warrior chief went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn42.3:1.2.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante, pubbakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ yodhājīvānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:
sn42.3:1.2.eng: “Sir, I have heard that the warriors of the past who were tutors of tutors said:

sn42.3:1.3.pli: ‘yo so yodhājīvo saṅgāme ussahati vāyamati, tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare hananti pariyāpādenti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā parajitānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī’ti.
sn42.3:1.3.eng: ‘Suppose a warrior, while striving and struggling in battle, is killed and finished off by his foes. When his body breaks up, after death, he’s reborn in the company of the gods of the fallen.’

sn42.3:1.4.eng: What does the Buddha say about this?”

sn42.3:1.5.pli: “Alaṃ, gāmaṇi, tiṭṭhatetaṃ; mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī”ti.
sn42.3:1.5.eng: “Enough, chief, let it be. Don’t ask me that.”

sn42.3:1.7.pli: tatiyampi kho yodhājīvo gāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn42.3:1.7.eng: And for a third time the warrior chief said to the Buddha:

sn42.3:1.8.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante, pubbakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ yodhājīvānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:
sn42.3:1.8.eng: “Sir, I have heard that the warriors of the past who were tutors of tutors said:

sn42.3:1.9.pli: ‘yo so yodhājīvo saṅgāme ussahati vāyamati, tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare hananti pariyāpādenti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā parajitānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī’ti.
sn42.3:1.9.eng: ‘Suppose a warrior, while striving and struggling in battle, is killed and finished off by his foes. When his body breaks up, after death, he’s reborn in the company of the gods of the fallen.’

sn42.3:1.10.eng: What does the Buddha say about this?”

sn42.3:2.1.eng: “Clearly, chief, I’m not getting through to you when I say:

sn42.3:2.2.pli: ‘alaṃ, gāmaṇi, tiṭṭhatetaṃ; mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī’ti.
sn42.3:2.2.eng: ‘Enough, chief, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’

sn42.3:2.4.pli: Yo so, gāmaṇi, yodhājīvo saṅgāme ussahati vāyamati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ pubbe gahitaṃ dukkaṭaṃ duppaṇihitaṃ:
sn42.3:2.4.eng: When a warrior strives and struggles in battle, their mind is already low, degraded, and misdirected as they think:

sn42.3:2.5.pli: ‘ime sattā haññantu vā bajjhantu vā ucchijjantu vā vinassantu vā mā vā ahesuṃ iti vā’ti.
sn42.3:2.5.eng: ‘May these sentient beings be killed, slaughtered, slain, destroyed, or annihilated!’

sn42.3:2.6.pli: Tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare hananti pariyāpādenti;
sn42.3:2.6.eng: His foes kill him and finish him off, and

sn42.3:2.7.pli: so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā parajito nāma nirayo tattha upapajjatīti.
sn42.3:2.7.eng: when his body breaks up, after death, he’s reborn in the hell called ‘The Fallen’.

sn42.3:2.8.pli: Sace kho panassa evaṃ diṭṭhi hoti:
sn42.3:2.8.eng: But if you have such a view:

sn42.3:2.9.pli: ‘yo so yodhājīvo saṅgāme ussahati vāyamati tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare hananti pariyāpādenti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā parajitānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī’ti, sāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi.
sn42.3:2.9.eng: ‘Suppose a warrior, while striving and struggling in battle, is killed and finished off by his foes. When his body breaks up, after death, he’s reborn in the company of the gods of the fallen.’ This is your wrong view.

sn42.3:2.10.pli: Micchādiṭṭhikassa kho panāhaṃ, gāmaṇi, purisapuggalassa dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ vadāmi—
sn42.3:2.10.eng: An individual with wrong view is reborn in one of two places, I say:

sn42.3:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, yodhājīvo gāmaṇi parodi, assūni pavattesi.
sn42.3:3.1.eng: When he said this, Dustin the warrior chief cried and burst out in tears.

sn42.3:3.2.eng: “This is what I didn’t get through to you when I said:

sn42.3:3.3.pli: ‘alaṃ, gāmaṇi, tiṭṭhatetaṃ; mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī’”ti.
sn42.3:3.3.eng: ‘Enough, chief, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’”

sn42.3:3.4.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhante, etaṃ rodāmi yaṃ maṃ bhagavā evamāha;
sn42.3:3.4.eng: “Sir, I’m not crying because of what the Buddha said.

sn42.3:3.5.pli: api cāhaṃ, bhante, pubbakehi ācariyapācariyehi yodhājīvehi dīgharattaṃ nikato vañcito paluddho:
sn42.3:3.5.eng: But sir, for a long time I’ve been cheated, tricked, and deceived by the warriors of the past who were tutors of tutors, who said:

sn42.3:3.6.pli: ‘yo so yodhājīvo saṅgāme ussahati vāyamati, tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare hananti pariyāpādenti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā parajitānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī’”ti.
sn42.3:3.6.eng: ‘Suppose a warrior, while striving and struggling in battle, is killed and finished off by his foes. When his body breaks up, after death, he’s reborn in the company of the gods of the fallen.’

sn42.3:3.8.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn42.4:1.1.pli: Atha kho hatthāroho gāmaṇi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā …pe…
sn42.4:1.1.eng: Then an elephant warrior chief went up to the Buddha …

sn42.4:1.2.eng: “From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn42.5:1.1.pli: Atha kho assāroho gāmaṇi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho assāroho gāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn42.5:1.1.eng: Then a cavalry chief went up to the Buddha …

sn42.5:1.2.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante, pubbakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ assārohānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:

sn42.5:1.3.pli: ‘yo so assāroho saṅgāme ussahati vāyamati, tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare hananti pariyāpādenti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā parajitānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī’ti.

sn42.5:1.5.pli: “Alaṃ, gāmaṇi, tiṭṭhatetaṃ; mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī”ti.

sn42.5:2.2.pli: tatiyampi kho assāroho gāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

sn42.5:2.3.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante, pubbakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ assārohānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:

sn42.5:2.4.pli: ‘yo so assāroho saṅgāme ussahati vāyamati, tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare hananti pariyāpādenti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā parajitānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī’ti.

sn42.5:3.2.pli: ‘alaṃ, gāmaṇi, tiṭṭhatetaṃ; mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī’ti.

sn42.5:3.4.pli: Yo so, gāmaṇi, assāroho saṅgāme ussahati vāyamati tassa taṃ cittaṃ pubbe gahitaṃ dukkaṭaṃ duppaṇihitaṃ:

sn42.5:3.5.pli: ‘ime sattā haññantu vā bajjhantu vā ucchijjantu vā vinassantu vā mā ahesuṃ iti vā’ti.

sn42.5:3.6.pli: Tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare hananti pariyāpādenti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā parajito nāma nirayo tattha upapajjati.

sn42.5:3.7.pli: Sace kho panassa evaṃ diṭṭhi hoti:

sn42.5:3.8.pli: ‘yo so assāroho saṅgāme ussahati vāyamati, tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare hananti pariyāpādenti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā parajitānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī’ti, sāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi.

sn42.5:3.9.pli: Micchādiṭṭhikassa kho panāhaṃ, gāmaṇi, purisapuggalassa dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ vadāmi—

sn42.5:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, assāroho gāmaṇi parodi, assūni pavattesi.

sn42.5:4.3.pli: ‘alaṃ, gāmaṇi, tiṭṭhatetaṃ; mā maṃ etaṃ pucchī’”ti.

sn42.5:4.4.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhante, etaṃ rodāmi yaṃ maṃ bhagavā evamāha.

sn42.5:4.5.pli: Api cāhaṃ, bhante, pubbakehi ācariyapācariyehi assārohehi dīgharattaṃ nikato vañcito paluddho:

sn42.5:4.6.pli: ‘yo so assāroho saṅgāme ussahati vāyamati, tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare hananti pariyāpādenti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā parajitānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī’”ti.

sn42.5:4.8.eng: “From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn42.6:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā nāḷandāyaṃ viharati pāvārikambavane.
sn42.6:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Nāḷandā in Pāvārika’s mango grove.

sn42.6:1.2.pli: Atha kho asibandhakaputto gāmaṇi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho asibandhakaputto gāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn42.6:1.2.eng: Then Asibandhaka’s son the chief went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn42.6:2.1.pli: “brāhmaṇā, bhante, pacchā bhūmakā kāmaṇḍalukā sevālamālikā udakorohakā aggiparicārakā.
sn42.6:2.1.eng: “Sir, there are western brahmins draped with moss who carry pitchers, immerse themselves in water, and serve the sacred flame.

sn42.6:2.2.pli: Te mataṃ kālaṅkataṃ uyyāpenti nāma saññāpenti nāma saggaṃ nāma okkāmenti.
sn42.6:2.2.eng: When someone has passed away, they truly lift them up, raise them up, and guide them along to heaven.

sn42.6:2.3.pli: Bhagavā pana, bhante, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho pahoti tathā kātuṃ yathā sabbo loko kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyyā”ti?
sn42.6:2.3.eng: But what about the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha: is he able to ensure that the whole world will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm when their body breaks up, after death?”

sn42.6:3.1.pli: “Tena hi, gāmaṇi, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya tathā naṃ byākareyyāsīti.
sn42.6:3.1.eng: “Well then, chief, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

sn42.6:4.2.pli: idhassa puriso pāṇātipātī adinnādāyī kāmesumicchācārī musāvādī pisuṇavāco pharusavāco samphappalāpī abhijjhālu byāpannacitto micchādiṭṭhiko.
sn42.6:4.2.eng: Take an individual who kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, and have wrong view.

sn42.6:4.3.pli: Tamenaṃ mahājanakāyo saṅgamma samāgamma āyāceyya thomeyya pañjaliko anuparisakkeyya:
sn42.6:4.3.eng: And a large crowd comes together to offer up supplication and entreaty, circumambulating them with joined palms and saying:

sn42.6:4.4.pli: ‘ayaṃ puriso kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjatū’ti.
sn42.6:4.4.eng: ‘When this person’s body breaks up, after death, may they be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm!’

sn42.6:4.6.pli: api nu so puriso mahato janakāyassa āyācanahetu vā thomanahetu vā pañjalikā anuparisakkanahetu vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyyā”ti?
sn42.6:4.6.eng: Would that person be reborn in heaven because of their supplications?”

sn42.6:5.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, gāmaṇi, puriso mahatiṃ puthusilaṃ gambhīre udakarahade pakkhipeyya.
sn42.6:5.1.eng: “Chief, suppose a person were to throw a broad rock into a deep lake.

sn42.6:5.2.pli: Tamenaṃ mahā janakāyo saṅgamma samāgamma āyāceyya thomeyya pañjaliko anuparisakkeyya:
sn42.6:5.2.eng: And a large crowd was to come together to offer up supplication and entreaty, circumambulating it with joined palms, and saying:

sn42.6:5.3.pli: ‘ummujja, bho puthusile, uplava, bho puthusile, thalamuplava, bho puthusile’ti.
sn42.6:5.3.eng: ‘Rise, good rock! Float, good rock! Float to shore, good rock!’

sn42.6:5.5.pli: api nu sā puthusilā mahato janakāyassa āyācanahetu vā thomanahetu vā pañjalikā anuparisakkanahetu vā ummujjeyya vā uplaveyya vā thalaṃ vā uplaveyyā”ti?
sn42.6:5.5.eng: Would that broad rock rise up or float because of their supplications?”

sn42.6:5.7.pli: “Evameva kho, gāmaṇi, yo so puriso pāṇātipātī adinnādāyī kāmesumicchācārī musāvādī pisuṇavāco pharusavāco samphappalāpī abhijjhālu byāpannacitto micchādiṭṭhiko.
sn42.6:5.7.eng: “In the same way, take a person who kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, and have wrong view.

sn42.6:5.8.pli: Kiñcāpi taṃ mahā janakāyo saṅgamma samāgamma āyāceyya thomeyya pañjaliko anuparisakkeyya:
sn42.6:5.8.eng: Even though a large crowd comes together to offer up supplication and entreaty …

sn42.6:5.9.pli: ‘ayaṃ puriso kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjatū’ti, atha kho so puriso kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyya.
sn42.6:5.9.eng: when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

sn42.6:6.2.pli: idhassa puriso pāṇātipātā paṭivirato adinnādānā paṭivirato kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato musāvādā paṭivirato pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato samphappalāpā paṭivirato anabhijjhālu abyāpannacitto sammādiṭṭhiko.
sn42.6:6.2.eng: Take an individual who doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, and have right view.

sn42.6:6.3.pli: Tamenaṃ mahā janakāyo saṅgamma samāgamma āyāceyya thomeyya pañjaliko anuparisakkeyya:
sn42.6:6.3.eng: And a large crowd comes together to offer up supplication and entreaty, circumambulating them with joined palms and saying:

sn42.6:6.4.pli: ‘ayaṃ puriso kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjatū’ti.
sn42.6:6.4.eng: ‘When this person’s body breaks up, after death, may they be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell!’

sn42.6:6.6.pli: api nu so puriso mahato janakāyassa āyācanahetu vā thomanahetu vā pañjalikā anuparisakkanahetu vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyyā”ti?
sn42.6:6.6.eng: Would that person be reborn in hell because of their supplications?”

sn42.6:7.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, gāmaṇi, puriso sappikumbhaṃ vā telakumbhaṃ vā gambhīre udakarahade ogāhetvā bhindeyya. Tatra yāssa sakkharā vā kaṭhalā vā sā adhogāmī assa; yañca khvassa tatra sappi vā telaṃ vā taṃ uddhaṃ gāmi assa.
sn42.6:7.1.eng: “Chief, suppose a person were to sink a pot of ghee or oil into a deep lake and break it open. Its shards and chips would sink down, while the ghee or oil in it would rise up.

sn42.6:7.2.pli: Tamenaṃ mahā janakāyo saṅgamma samāgamma āyāceyya thomeyya pañjaliko anuparisakkeyya:
sn42.6:7.2.eng: And a large crowd was to come together to offer up supplication and entreaty, circumambulating it with joined palms and saying:

sn42.6:7.3.pli: ‘osīda, bho sappitela, saṃsīda, bho sappitela, adho gaccha, bho sappitelā’ti.
sn42.6:7.3.eng: ‘Sink, good ghee or oil! Descend, good ghee or oil! Go down, good ghee or oil!’

sn42.6:7.5.pli: api nu taṃ sappitelaṃ mahato janakāyassa āyācanahetu vā thomanahetu vā pañjalikā anuparisakkanahetu vā osīdeyya vā saṃsīdeyya vā adho vā gaccheyyā”ti?
sn42.6:7.5.eng: Would that ghee or oil sink and descend because of their supplications?”

sn42.6:8.1.pli: “Evameva kho, gāmaṇi, yo so puriso pāṇātipātā paṭivirato, adinnādānā paṭivirato, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato, musāvādā paṭivirato, pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato, pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato, samphappalāpā paṭivirato, anabhijjhālu, abyāpannacitto, sammādiṭṭhiko,
sn42.6:8.1.eng: “In the same way, take an individual who doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, and have right view.

sn42.6:8.2.pli: kiñcāpi taṃ mahā janakāyo saṅgamma samāgamma āyāceyya thomeyya pañjaliko anuparisakkeyya:
sn42.6:8.2.eng: Even though a large crowd comes together to offer up supplication and entreaty …

sn42.6:8.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ puriso kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjatū’ti, atha kho so puriso kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyyā”ti.
sn42.6:8.3.eng: when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”

sn42.6:8.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, asibandhakaputto gāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn42.6:8.4.eng: When he said this, Asibandhaka’s son the chief said to the Buddha,

sn42.6:8.6.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn42.7:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā nāḷandāyaṃ viharati pāvārikambavane.
sn42.7:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Nāḷandā in Pāvārika’s mango grove.

sn42.7:1.2.pli: Atha kho asibandhakaputto gāmaṇi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho asibandhakaputto gāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn42.7:1.2.eng: Then Asibandhaka’s son the chief went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn42.7:1.3.eng: “Sir, doesn’t the Buddha live full of sympathy for all living beings?”

sn42.7:1.5.pli: “Atha kiñcarahi, bhante, bhagavā ekaccānaṃ sakkaccaṃ dhammaṃ deseti, ekaccānaṃ no tathā sakkaccaṃ dhammaṃ desetī”ti?
sn42.7:1.5.eng: “So why then, sir, do you teach some people thoroughly and others less thoroughly?”

sn42.7:1.6.pli: “Tena hi, gāmaṇi, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
sn42.7:1.6.eng: “Well then, chief, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

sn42.7:1.7.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, gāmaṇi, idhassu kassakassa gahapatino tīṇi khettāni—ekaṃ khettaṃ aggaṃ, ekaṃ khettaṃ majjhimaṃ, ekaṃ khettaṃ hīnaṃ jaṅgalaṃ ūsaraṃ pāpabhūmi.
sn42.7:1.7.eng: What do you think? Suppose a farmer has three fields: one’s good, one’s average, and one’s poor—bad ground of sand and salt.

sn42.7:1.8.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, gāmaṇi, asu kassako gahapati bījāni patiṭṭhāpetukāmo kattha paṭhamaṃ patiṭṭhāpeyya, yaṃ vā aduṃ khettaṃ aggaṃ, yaṃ vā aduṃ khettaṃ majjhimaṃ, yaṃ vā aduṃ khettaṃ hīnaṃ jaṅgalaṃ ūsaraṃ pāpabhūmī”ti?
sn42.7:1.8.eng: What do you think? When that farmer wants to plant seeds, where would he plant them first: the good field, the average one, or the poor one?”

sn42.7:1.9.pli: “Asu, bhante, kassako gahapati bījāni patiṭṭhāpetukāmo yaṃ aduṃ khettaṃ aggaṃ tattha patiṭṭhāpeyya. Tattha patiṭṭhāpetvā yaṃ aduṃ khettaṃ majjhimaṃ tattha patiṭṭhāpeyya. Tattha patiṭṭhāpetvā yaṃ aduṃ khettaṃ hīnaṃ jaṅgalaṃ ūsaraṃ pāpabhūmi tattha patiṭṭhāpeyyapi, nopi patiṭṭhāpeyya.
sn42.7:1.9.eng: “Sir, he’d plant them first in the good field, then the average, then he may or may not plant seed in the poor field.

sn42.7:1.11.eng: Because at least it can be fodder for the cattle.”

sn42.7:2.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, gāmaṇi, yaṃ aduṃ khettaṃ aggaṃ; evameva mayhaṃ bhikkhubhikkhuniyo.
sn42.7:2.1.eng: “To me, the monks and nuns are like the good field.

sn42.7:2.2.pli: Tesāhaṃ dhammaṃ desemi—ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ, sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsemi.
sn42.7:2.2.eng: I teach them the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And I reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

sn42.7:2.4.pli: Ete hi, gāmaṇi, maṃdīpā maṃleṇā maṃtāṇā maṃsaraṇā viharanti.
sn42.7:2.4.eng: Because they live with me as their island, protection, shelter, and refuge.

sn42.7:2.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, gāmaṇi, yaṃ aduṃ khettaṃ majjhimaṃ; evameva mayhaṃ upāsakaupāsikāyo.
sn42.7:2.5.eng: To me, the laymen and laywomen are like the average field.

sn42.7:2.6.pli: Tesaṃ pāhaṃ dhammaṃ desemi—ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ, sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsemi.
sn42.7:2.6.eng: I also teach them the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And I reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

sn42.7:2.8.pli: Ete hi, gāmaṇi, maṃdīpā maṃleṇā maṃtāṇā maṃsaraṇā viharanti.
sn42.7:2.8.eng: Because they live with me as their island, protection, shelter, and refuge.

sn42.7:2.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, gāmaṇi, yaṃ aduṃ khettaṃ hīnaṃ jaṅgalaṃ ūsaraṃ pāpabhūmi; evameva mayhaṃ aññatitthiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇaparibbājakā.
sn42.7:2.9.eng: To me, the ascetics, brahmins, and wanderers of other religions are like the poor field, the bad ground of sand and salt.

sn42.7:2.10.pli: Tesaṃ pāhaṃ dhammaṃ desemi—ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsemi.
sn42.7:2.10.eng: I also teach them the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And I reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

sn42.7:2.12.pli: Appeva nāma ekaṃ padampi ājāneyyuṃ taṃ nesaṃ assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyāti.
sn42.7:2.12.eng: Hopefully they might understand even a single sentence, which would be for their lasting welfare and happiness.

sn42.7:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, gāmaṇi, purisassa tayo udakamaṇikā—eko udakamaṇiko acchiddo ahārī aparihārī, eko udakamaṇiko acchiddo hārī parihārī, eko udakamaṇiko chiddo hārī parihārī.
sn42.7:3.1.eng: Suppose a person had three water jars: one that’s uncracked and nonporous; one that’s uncracked but porous; and one that’s cracked and porous.

sn42.7:3.2.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, gāmaṇi, asu puriso udakaṃ nikkhipitukāmo kattha paṭhamaṃ nikkhipeyya, yo vā so udakamaṇiko acchiddo ahārī aparihārī, yo vā so udakamaṇiko acchiddo hārī parihārī, yo vā so udakamaṇiko chiddo hārī parihārī”ti?
sn42.7:3.2.eng: What do you think? When that person wants to store water, where would they store it first: in the jar that’s uncracked and nonporous, the one that’s uncracked but porous, or the one that’s cracked and porous?”

sn42.7:3.3.pli: “Asu, bhante, puriso udakaṃ nikkhipitukāmo, yo so udakamaṇiko acchiddo ahārī aparihārī tattha nikkhipeyya, tattha nikkhipitvā, yo so udakamaṇiko acchiddo hārī parihārī tattha nikkhipeyya, tattha nikkhipitvā, yo so udakamaṇiko chiddo hārī parihārī tattha nikkhipeyyapi, nopi nikkhipeyya.
sn42.7:3.3.eng: “Sir, they’d store water first in the jar that’s uncracked and nonporous, then the one that’s uncracked but porous, then they may or may not store water in the one that’s cracked and porous.

sn42.7:3.5.eng: Because at least it can be used for washing the dishes.”

sn42.7:4.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, gāmaṇi, yo so udakamaṇiko acchiddo ahārī aparihārī; evameva mayhaṃ bhikkhubhikkhuniyo.
sn42.7:4.1.eng: “To me, the monks and nuns are like the water jar that’s uncracked and nonporous.

sn42.7:4.2.pli: Tesāhaṃ dhammaṃ desemi—ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsemi.
sn42.7:4.2.eng: I teach them the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And I reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

sn42.7:4.4.pli: Ete hi, gāmaṇi, maṃdīpā maṃleṇā maṃtāṇā maṃsaraṇā viharanti.
sn42.7:4.4.eng: Because they live with me as their island, protection, shelter, and refuge.

sn42.7:4.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, gāmaṇi, yo so udakamaṇiko acchiddo hārī parihārī; evameva mayhaṃ upāsakaupāsikāyo.
sn42.7:4.5.eng: To me, the laymen and laywomen are like the water jar that’s uncracked but porous.

sn42.7:4.6.pli: Tesāhaṃ dhammaṃ desemi—ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsemi.
sn42.7:4.6.eng: I teach them the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And I reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

sn42.7:4.8.pli: Ete hi, gāmaṇi, maṃdīpā maṃleṇā maṃtāṇā maṃsaraṇā viharanti.
sn42.7:4.8.eng: Because they live with me as their island, protection, shelter, and refuge.

sn42.7:4.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, gāmaṇi, yo so udakamaṇiko chiddo hārī parihārī; evameva mayhaṃ aññatitthiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇaparibbājakā.
sn42.7:4.9.eng: To me, the ascetics, brahmins, and wanderers of other religions are like the water jar that’s cracked and porous.

sn42.7:4.10.pli: Tesāhaṃ dhammaṃ desemi—ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsemi.
sn42.7:4.10.eng: I also teach them the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And I reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

sn42.7:4.12.pli: Appeva nāma ekaṃ padampi ājāneyyuṃ, taṃ nesaṃ assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
sn42.7:4.12.eng: Hopefully they might understand even a single sentence, which would be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”

sn42.7:5.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, asibandhakaputto gāmaṇi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn42.7:5.1.eng: When he said this, Asibandhaka’s son the chief said to the Buddha,

sn42.7:5.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn42.7:5.3.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
